Four-body central configurations with one pair of opposite sides parallel

Manuele Santoprete Department of Mathematics, Wilfrid Laurier University E-mail: msantopr@wlu.ca
Abstract

We study four-body central configurations with one pair of opposite sides parallel. We use a novel constraint to write the central configuration equations in this special case, using distances as variables. We prove that, for a given ordering of the mutual distances, a trapezoidal central configuration must have a certain partial ordering of the masses. We also show that if opposite masses of a four-body trapezoidal central configuration are equal, then the configuration has a line of symmetry and it must be a kite. In contrast to the general four-body case, we show that if the two adjacent masses bounding the shortest side are equal, then the configuration must be an isosceles trapezoid, and the remaining two masses must also be equal.

Contents
  1. 1 Introduction
  2. 2 Another Planarity Conditions
  3. 3 Planarity Condition and c.c equations
  4. 4 Relationship to Cayley-Menger
  5. 5 Some Applications of the c.c. equations

(3)

If we let I‚Äã(ùê™)ùêºùê™I(\mathbf{q}) denote the moment of inertia, that is,

we can write equations (3) as

‚àáU‚Äã(ùê™)=Œª‚Äã‚àáI‚Äã(ùê™).‚àáùëàùê™ùúÜ‚àáùêºùê™\nabla U(\mathbf{q})=\lambda\nabla I(\mathbf{q}). (4)

Viewing ŒªùúÜ\lambda as a Lagrange multiplier, a central configuration is simply a critical point of UùëàU subject to the constraint IùêºI equals a constant.

A central configuration is planar if the four points P1,P2,P3subscriptùëÉ1subscriptùëÉ2subscriptùëÉ3P_{1},P_{2},P_{3}, and P4subscriptùëÉ4P_{4} lie on the same plane. Equations (3), and (4) also describe planar central configurations provided ùê™i‚àà‚Ñù2subscriptùê™ùëñsuperscript‚Ñù2\mathbf{q}_{i}\in\mathbb{R}^{2} for i=1,‚Ä¶‚Äã4ùëñ1‚Ä¶4i=1,\ldots 4. We say that a planar configuration is degenerate if two or more points coincide, or if more than two points lie on the same line. Non-degenerate planar configurations can be classified as either concave or convex. A concave configuration has one point which is located strictly inside the convex hull of the other three, whereas a convex configuration does not have a point contained in the convex hull of the other three points. Any convex configuration determines a convex quadrilateral (for a precise definition of quadrilateral see for example [5]). In a planar convex configuration we say that the points are ordered sequentially if they are numbered consecutively while traversing the boundary of the corresponding convex quadrilateral. In this paper we are interested in studying trapezoidal central configurations, that is, those c.c.‚Äôs for which two of the opposite sides are parallel (see Figure 1). Non-degenerate trapezoidal central configurations are necessarily convex.

The four body problem has a long and distinguished history. In 1900 Dziobek derived equations for central configurations of four bodies with distances as variables [14]. In 1932 McMillan and Bartky used similar equations to obtain many important new results [19]. In 1996 Albouy [1, 2] gave a complete classifications of the four-body c.c.‚Äôs with equal masses. More recently, in 2006 Hampton and Moeckel [16] proved the finiteness of the number of c.c.‚Äôs. Other recent results of note, concerning four-body c.c.‚Äôs in the case some of the masses are equal, were obtained by the present author and Perez-Chavela, [20], Albouy, Fu and Sun [4], and Fernandes, Llibre and Mello [15]. Further results for the four-body were recently attained by Cors and Roberts [9], Corbera, Cors and Roberts [8], Deng, Li and Zhang [11, 12] and Xie [24], just to mention a few. Particularly important for this paper is the work of Cors and Roberts [9] which inspired for the approach we take here. Additionally, certain bifurcations in the four-body problem, and several planarity conditions and their applications to four-body c.c.‚Äôs were obtained by the present author in [21] and [22], respectively.

Let ùê´=(r12,r13,r14,r23,r24,r34)‚àà(‚Ñù+)6ùê´subscriptùëü12subscriptùëü13subscriptùëü14subscriptùëü23subscriptùëü24subscriptùëü34superscriptsuperscript‚Ñù6\mathbf{r}=(r_{12},r_{13},r_{14},r_{23},r_{24},r_{34})\in(\mathbb{R}^{+})^{6} be a vector of mutual distances. The conditions for which such vector determines a realizable configuration of four bodies in Euclidean space can be expressed by the Cayley-Menger criterion, that we state below. The Cayley-Menger determinant of four points P1,‚Ä¶‚ÄãP4subscriptùëÉ1‚Ä¶subscriptùëÉ4P_{1},\ldots P_{4} is

H‚Äã(ùê´)=|0111110r122r132r1421r1220r232r2421r132r2320r3421r142r242r3420.|.ùêªùê´matrix0111110subscriptsuperscriptùëü212subscriptsuperscriptùëü213subscriptsuperscriptùëü2141subscriptsuperscriptùëü2120subscriptsuperscriptùëü223subscriptsuperscriptùëü2241subscriptsuperscriptùëü213subscriptsuperscriptùëü2230subscriptsuperscriptùëü2341subscriptsuperscriptùëü214subscriptsuperscriptùëü224subscriptsuperscriptùëü2340H(\mathbf{r})=\begin{vmatrix}0&1&1&1&1\\ 1&0&r^{2}_{12}&r^{2}_{13}&r^{2}_{14}\\ 1&r^{2}_{12}&0&r^{2}_{23}&r^{2}_{24}\\ 1&r^{2}_{13}&r^{2}_{23}&0&r^{2}_{34}\\ 1&r^{2}_{14}&r^{2}_{24}&r^{2}_{34}&0.\end{vmatrix}.

A configuration is geometrically realizable if and only if the Cayley-Menger determinant of each subconfiguration of two or more points is ‚â•0absent0\geq 0 when the number of points is even, and ‚â§0absent0\leq 0 when it is odd. See, for instance, the book of Blumenthal [7] or Theorem 9.7.3.4 and Exercise 9.14.23 in [6]. Note that an equivalent characterization can be given in terms of Borchardt‚Äôs quadratic form, see [3, 23]. In the remainder of this paper we assume that ùê´ùê´\mathbf{r} is geometrically realizable.

In the four-body problem the mutual distances are not independent so that describing planar four-body central configurations requires an additional constraint. Following Dziobek [14] it is customary to use the following planarity condition,

Planarity Condition 1.

P1,P2,P3,P4‚àà‚Ñù3subscriptùëÉ1subscriptùëÉ2subscriptùëÉ3subscriptùëÉ4superscript‚Ñù3P_{1},P_{2},P_{3},P_{4}\in\mathbb{R}^{3} are coplanar if and only if the Cayley-Menger determinant determined by these four points is 00, that is, H‚Äã(ùê´)=0ùêªùê´0H(\mathbf{r})=0.

In this paper we use a different constraint that not only gives planarity of the configuration, but also restricts the configuration to be trapezoidal. This planarity conditions complements the list given in [22]. Our approach parallels the treatment of the co-circular for body problem given by Cors and Roberts in [9]. The new constraint is introduced in Section 2. In Section 3 we derive the equations for the trapezoidal central configurations. In Section 4 we study the relationship between the Cayley-Menger constraint and the constraint used in the paper, and show that, as expected, the gradients of these restrictions are collinear at trapezoidal configurations. In Section 5 we prove that, for a given ordering of the mutual distances, a trapezoidal central configuration must have a certain partial ordering of the masses. This result is by necessity weaker than the analogous result for co-circular configurations where one obtains a total ordering (see [9]). We also prove that if opposite masses of a four-body trapezoidal central configuration are equal, then the configuration has a line of symmetry and is a kite. This is a special case of the well known result of Albouy, Fu and Sun [4]. A similar result also holds in the case the two adjacent masses bounding the shortest side are equal. In this case the configuration is an isosceles trapezoid, and the remaining two masses must also be equal. Finally, we show that, in contrast to the co-circular case, when the two adjacent masses bounding the longest side are equal there are asymmetric solutions.

2 Another Planarity Conditions

Hence,

4‚ÄãŒî2=a2‚Äãc2‚àí14‚Äã(e2+f2‚àíb2‚àíd2)2.4superscriptŒî2superscriptùëé2superscriptùëê214superscriptsuperscriptùëí2superscriptùëì2superscriptùëè2superscriptùëë224\,\Delta^{2}=a^{2}c^{2}-\frac{1}{4}(e^{2}+f^{2}-b^{2}-d^{2})^{2}.

‚àé

In the case of a planar configuration ŒîŒî\Delta can be interpreted as the absolute value of the difference of the areas of the triangles whose bases are the sides ùêõùêõ\mathbf{b} and ùêùùêù\mathbf{d} of a convex quadrilateral, and whose vertices coincide with the intersection of the diagonals (see [17] page 208). Note that ŒîŒî\Delta can also be viewed as the area of a crossed quadrilateral (see [10]).

There are two ways to obtain a planarity condition from this. One is to impose that ŒîŒî\Delta is equal to the absolute value of the difference of the areas A3subscriptùê¥3A_{3} and A4subscriptùê¥4A_{4} (or the absolute value of the difference between A1subscriptùê¥1A_{1} and A2subscriptùê¥2A_{2}). Here Aisubscriptùê¥ùëñA_{i} is the area of the triangle whose vertices contain all bodies except for the iùëñi-th body. The second approach, which is the one we take here, is to impose that Œî=0Œî0\Delta=0

Planarity Condition 2.

Suppose Œî=12‚Äã‚Äñùêö√óùêú‚ÄñŒî12normùêöùêú\Delta=\frac{1}{2}\|\mathbf{a}\times\mathbf{c}\|. Then, Œî=0Œî0\Delta=0 if and only if ùêöùêö\mathbf{a} and ùêúùêú\mathbf{c} are parallel and the configuration is planar.

Proof.

Clearly, if ‚Äñùêö√óùêú‚Äñ=0normùêöùêú0\|\mathbf{a}\times\mathbf{c}\|=0 the vectors ùêöùêö\mathbf{a} and ùêúùêú\mathbf{c} are parallel, in which case the configuration is planar because the four points lie on two parallel lines. Conversely, if the configuration is planar with ùêöùêö\mathbf{a} and ùêúùêú\mathbf{c} parallel, then ‚Äñùêö√óùêú‚Äñ=0normùêöùêú0\|\mathbf{a}\times\mathbf{c}\|=0. ‚àé

Note that the above condition can be written explicitly in terms of mutual distances as a2‚Äãc2=14‚Äã(e2+f2‚àíb2‚àíd2)2superscriptùëé2superscriptùëê214superscriptsuperscriptùëí2superscriptùëì2superscriptùëè2superscriptùëë22a^{2}c^{2}=\frac{1}{4}(e^{2}+f^{2}-b^{2}-d^{2})^{2}, or

(2‚Äãa‚Äãc+e2+f2‚àíb2‚àíd2)‚Äã(2‚Äãa‚Äãc‚àíe2‚àíf2+b2+d2)=0.2ùëéùëêsuperscriptùëí2superscriptùëì2superscriptùëè2superscriptùëë22ùëéùëêsuperscriptùëí2superscriptùëì2superscriptùëè2superscriptùëë20(2ac+e^{2}+f^{2}-b^{2}-d^{2})(2ac-e^{2}-f^{2}+b^{2}+d^{2})=0. (5)

For the remainder of this paper we will assume that any trapezoidal configuration satisfying the planarity condition above is ordered sequentially so that r12,r34subscriptùëü12subscriptùëü34r_{12},r_{34} are the lengths of the bases of the trapezoid, r23subscriptùëü23r_{23} and r14subscriptùëü14r_{14} are the lengths of legs, and r13subscriptùëü13r_{13} and r24subscriptùëü24r_{24} are the lengths of the diagonals. In this case one has

(2‚Äãa‚Äãc‚àíe2‚àíf2+b2+d2)=0,2ùëéùëêsuperscriptùëí2superscriptùëì2superscriptùëè2superscriptùëë20(2ac-e^{2}-f^{2}+b^{2}+d^{2})=0, (6)

which is known as a necessary and sufficient condition for a convex quadrilateral with consecutive sides a,b,c,dùëéùëèùëêùëëa,b,c,d and diagonals e,fùëíùëìe,f to be a trapezoid with parallel sides aùëéa and cùëêc. See for example [18].

To double check that for realizable configurations equation (6) implies planarity, we proceed as follows. Substituting e2=2‚Äãa‚Äãc‚àíf2+b2+d2superscriptùëí22ùëéùëêsuperscriptùëì2superscriptùëè2superscriptùëë2e^{2}=2ac-f^{2}+b^{2}+d^{2} into the Cayley-Menger determinant yields

‚àí2‚Äã(r122‚Äãr34+r12‚Äãr232‚àír12‚Äãr242‚àír12‚Äãr342‚àír142‚Äãr34+r242‚Äãr34)2‚â§0.2superscriptsuperscriptsubscriptùëü122subscriptùëü34subscriptùëü12superscriptsubscriptùëü232subscriptùëü12superscriptsubscriptùëü242subscriptùëü12superscriptsubscriptùëü342superscriptsubscriptùëü142subscriptùëü34superscriptsubscriptùëü242subscriptùëü3420-2(r_{12}^{2}r_{34}+r_{12}r_{23}^{2}-r_{12}r_{24}^{2}-r_{12}r_{34}^{2}-r_{14}^{2}r_{34}+r_{24}^{2}r_{34})^{2}\leq 0.

By the Cayley-Menger criterion, this implies that for the mutual distances vector ùê´ùê´\mathbf{r} to correspond to a realizable configuration one must have

r122‚Äãr34+r12‚Äãr232‚àír12‚Äãr242‚àír12‚Äãr342‚àír142‚Äãr34+r242‚Äãr34=0,superscriptsubscriptùëü122subscriptùëü34subscriptùëü12superscriptsubscriptùëü232subscriptùëü12superscriptsubscriptùëü242subscriptùëü12superscriptsubscriptùëü342superscriptsubscriptùëü142subscriptùëü34superscriptsubscriptùëü242subscriptùëü340r_{12}^{2}r_{34}+r_{12}r_{23}^{2}-r_{12}r_{24}^{2}-r_{12}r_{34}^{2}-r_{14}^{2}r_{34}+r_{24}^{2}r_{34}=0,

which in turn implies that H‚Äã(ùê´)=0ùêªùê´0H(\mathbf{r})=0, and leads to the formulas (18) and (19) for the diagonals of a trapezoid.

We remark that if one imposes Ptolemy‚Äôs condition to study co-circular configurations, as done in [9], it is possible to see that any realizable configuration satisfying Ptolemy‚Äôs must be planar as a consequence of the Cayley-Menger criterion.

which is required of any planar 4-body central configuration (not only c.c.‚Äôs with parallel opposite sides).

Eliminating ŒªùúÜ\lambda from equation (15) and factoring gives the important relation

(r133‚àír123)‚Äã(r233‚àír343)‚Äã(r243‚àír143)=(r123‚àír143)‚Äã(r243‚àír343)‚Äã(r133‚àír233).superscriptsubscriptùëü133superscriptsubscriptùëü123superscriptsubscriptùëü233superscriptsubscriptùëü343superscriptsubscriptùëü243superscriptsubscriptùëü143superscriptsubscriptùëü123superscriptsubscriptùëü143superscriptsubscriptùëü243superscriptsubscriptùëü343superscriptsubscriptùëü133superscriptsubscriptùëü233(r_{13}^{3}-r_{12}^{3})(r_{23}^{3}-r_{34}^{3})(r_{24}^{3}-r_{14}^{3})=(r_{12}^{3}-r_{14}^{3})(r_{24}^{3}-r_{34}^{3})(r_{13}^{3}-r_{23}^{3}). (16)

Assuming the six mutual distances determine an actual configuration in the plane, this equation is necessary and sufficient for the existence of a four-body planar central configuration. Further restrictions are needed to ensure that the masses are positive.

Reasoning as in [9] it is possible to show that positivity of the masses implies that each side of the quadrilateral is shorter in length than either diagonal, and that the shortest exterior side must lie opposite the longest. Then, the longest side will be either one of the parallel sides or one of the remaining exterior sides. In the former case suppose r14subscriptùëü14r_{14} is the longest exterior side, then we have that r23subscriptùëü23r_{23} is the shortest, and thus

|r14‚àír23|>|r34‚àír12|.subscriptùëü14subscriptùëü23subscriptùëü34subscriptùëü12|r_{14}-r_{23}|>|r_{34}-r_{12}|.

However, four lengths can constitute the consecutive sides of a non-parallelogram trapezoid, with r12subscriptùëü12r_{12} and r34subscriptùëü34r_{34} the lengths of the parallel sides, only when

|r14‚àír23|<|r34‚àír12|<r14+r23,subscriptùëü14subscriptùëü23subscriptùëü34subscriptùëü12subscriptùëü14subscriptùëü23|r_{14}-r_{23}|<|r_{34}-r_{12}|<r_{14}+r_{23},

which contradicts the previous inequality. A similar reasoning shows that r23subscriptùëü23r_{23} cannot be the longest exterior side. Hence, in a trapezoidal central configuration, one of the legs cannot be the longest exterior side.

In the latter case, without any loss of generality, we can label the bodies so that r12subscriptùëü12r_{12} is the longest exterior side-length. Then, positivity of the masses implies that

r13,r24>r12‚â•r14,r23‚â•r34.formulae-sequencesubscriptùëü13subscriptùëü24subscriptùëü12subscriptùëü14subscriptùëü23subscriptùëü34r_{13},r_{24}>r_{12}\geq r_{14},r_{23}\geq r_{34}.

With an appropriate relabeling it is also possible to assume r14‚â•r23subscriptùëü14subscriptùëü23r_{14}\geq r_{23} (see [9]). This choice imposes r13‚â•r24subscriptùëü13subscriptùëü24r_{13}\geq r_{24}, and thus

r13‚â•r24>r12‚â•r14‚â•r23‚â•r34.subscriptùëü13subscriptùëü24subscriptùëü12subscriptùëü14subscriptùëü23subscriptùëü34r_{13}\geq r_{24}>r_{12}\geq r_{14}\geq r_{23}\geq r_{34}. (17)

To prove the relation between the diagonals, recall that the lengths of the diagonals in a trapezoid are given by (see [18]):

It follows that

since r12>r34subscriptùëü12subscriptùëü34r_{12}>r_{34}, and r14‚â•r23subscriptùëü14subscriptùëü23r_{14}\geq r_{23}.

Hence, without loss of generality we can restrict our analysis to the set

Œ©={ùê´‚àà(‚Ñù+)6:r13‚â•r24>r12‚â•r14‚â•r23‚â•r34}.Œ©conditional-setùê´superscriptsuperscript‚Ñù6subscriptùëü13subscriptùëü24subscriptùëü12subscriptùëü14subscriptùëü23subscriptùëü34\Omega=\{\mathbf{r}\in(\mathbb{R}^{+})^{6}:r_{13}\geq r_{24}>r_{12}\geq r_{14}\geq r_{23}\geq r_{34}\}.

From the different ratios of two masses that can be derived from equations(12-14), we obtain the following set of equations:

4 Relationship to Cayley-Menger

Let ŒîisubscriptŒîùëñ\Delta_{i} be the oriented area of the triangle whose vertices contain all bodies except for the iùëñi -th body. For a quadrilateral ordered sequentially, we have Œî1,Œî3>0subscriptŒî1subscriptŒî30\Delta_{1},\Delta_{3}>0 and Œî2,Œî4<0subscriptŒî2subscriptŒî40\Delta_{2},\Delta_{4}<0. The derivatives of the Cayley-Menger determinant at planar c.c.‚Äôs are given by the following formula due to Dziobek [14]

‚àÇH‚àÇri‚Äãj2‚Äã(ùê´)=‚àí32‚ÄãŒîi‚ÄãŒîj.ùêªsuperscriptsubscriptùëüùëñùëó2ùê´32subscriptŒîùëñsubscriptŒîùëó\frac{\partial H}{\partial r_{ij}^{2}}(\mathbf{r})=-32\Delta_{i}\Delta_{j}.

In a trapezoid the areas |Œîi|subscriptŒîùëñ|\Delta_{i}| take the form:

|Œî1|=|Œî2|=12‚Äãr34‚Äãh,|Œî3|=|Œî4|=12‚Äãr12‚Äãhformulae-sequencesubscriptŒî1subscriptŒî212subscriptùëü34‚ÑésubscriptŒî3subscriptŒî412subscriptùëü12‚Ñé|\Delta_{1}|=|\Delta_{2}|=\frac{1}{2}r_{34}h,\quad|\Delta_{3}|=|\Delta_{4}|=\frac{1}{2}r_{12}h

where h‚Ñéh is the height, that is, the distances between the opposite parallel sides. If the parallel sides have different lengths (i.e., r12‚â†r34subscriptùëü12subscriptùëü34r_{12}\neq r_{34}) the height of a trapezoid can be expressed in terms of mutual distances as follows:

h=(a‚àíc+d+e)‚Äã(‚àía+c+d+e)‚Äã(a+c‚àíd+e)‚Äã(a+c+d‚àíe)2‚Äã|a‚àíc|.‚Ñéùëéùëêùëëùëíùëéùëêùëëùëíùëéùëêùëëùëíùëéùëêùëëùëí2ùëéùëêh=\frac{\sqrt{(a-c+d+e)(-a+c+d+e)(a+c-d+e)(a+c+d-e)}}{2|a-c|}.

If r12=r34subscriptùëü12subscriptùëü34r_{12}=r_{34}, then the trapezoid reduces to a parallelogram, in which case, since the area is A=r12‚Äãhùê¥subscriptùëü12‚ÑéA=r_{12}h, we have

h=r12A‚Ñésubscriptùëü12ùê¥h=\frac{r_{12}}{A}

and Aùê¥A is given by Bretschneider‚Äôs formula for the area of a quadrilateral, that is,

A=12‚Äãe2‚Äãf2‚àí14‚Äã(b2+d2‚àía2‚àíc2)2.ùê¥12superscriptùëí2superscriptùëì214superscriptsuperscriptùëè2superscriptùëë2superscriptùëé2superscriptùëê22A=\frac{1}{2}\sqrt{e^{2}f^{2}-\frac{1}{4}(b^{2}+d^{2}-a^{2}-c^{2})^{2}}.

In any case, since

‚àÇH‚àÇri‚Äãj‚Äã(ùê´)=‚àÇH‚àÇri‚Äãj2‚Äã(ùê´)‚ãÖd‚Äã(ri‚Äãj2)d‚Äãri‚Äãj=‚àí64‚Äãri‚Äãj‚ÄãŒîi‚ÄãŒîjùêªsubscriptùëüùëñùëóùê´‚ãÖùêªsuperscriptsubscriptùëüùëñùëó2ùê´ùëësuperscriptsubscriptùëüùëñùëó2ùëësubscriptùëüùëñùëó64subscriptùëüùëñùëósubscriptŒîùëñsubscriptŒîùëó\frac{\partial H}{\partial r_{ij}}(\mathbf{r})=\frac{\partial H}{\partial r_{ij}^{2}}(\mathbf{r})\cdot\frac{d(r_{ij}^{2})}{dr_{ij}}=-64r_{ij}\,\Delta_{i}\Delta_{j}

we find that at a trapezoidal central configuration

‚àáH‚Äã(ùê´)=16‚Äãr12‚Äãr34‚Äãh2‚Äã(r34,‚àír13,r14,r23,‚àír24,r12),‚àáùêªùê´16subscriptùëü12subscriptùëü34superscript‚Ñé2subscriptùëü34subscriptùëü13subscriptùëü14subscriptùëü23subscriptùëü24subscriptùëü12\nabla H(\mathbf{r})=16r_{12}r_{34}h^{2}(r_{34},-r_{13},r_{14},r_{23},-r_{24},r_{12}),

where h‚Ñéh is defined above. On the other hand, the gradient of F‚Äã(ùê´)ùêπùê´F(\mathbf{r}) at a trapezoidal configuration is,

‚àáF‚Äã(ùê´)=2‚Äãr12‚Äãr34‚Äã(r34,‚àír13,r14,r23,‚àír24,r12).‚àáùêπùê´2subscriptùëü12subscriptùëü34subscriptùëü34subscriptùëü13subscriptùëü14subscriptùëü23subscriptùëü24subscriptùëü12\nabla F(\mathbf{r})=2r_{12}r_{34}(r_{34},-r_{13},r_{14},r_{23},-r_{24},r_{12}).

Comparing the two gradients above, we have the following proposition

Proposition 2.

For any trapezoidal central configuration ùê´ùê´\mathbf{r}

‚àáH‚Äã(ùê´)=8‚Äãh2‚Äã‚àáF‚Äã(ùê´).‚àáùêªùê´8superscript‚Ñé2‚àáùêπùê´\nabla H(\mathbf{r})=8h^{2}~{}\nabla F(\mathbf{r}).

In other words, on the set of geometrically realizable vectors for which both HùêªH and FùêπF vanish, the gradients of these two functions are parallel.

Note that a isosceles trapezoid central configurations is both a trapezoidal and co-circular. Therefore taking the proposition above together with Lemma 2.1 in [9] implies that on the set of geometrically realizable vectors for which HùêªH, FùêπF and P=r12‚Äãr34+r14‚Äãr23‚àír13‚Äãr24ùëÉsubscriptùëü12subscriptùëü34subscriptùëü14subscriptùëü23subscriptùëü13subscriptùëü24P=r_{12}r_{34}+r_{14}r_{23}-r_{13}r_{24} vanish the gradients of these three functions are parallel. Thus, the codimension one level surfaces defined by the equations H=0ùêª0H=0, F=0ùêπ0F=0, and P=0ùëÉ0P=0 meet tangentially at the isosceles trapezoid configurations.

5 Some Applications of the c.c. equations

In this section we apply equations (3)-(4) to obtain interesting results in the cases some of the masses are equal. We begin with two propositions that have a very simple proof.

Proposition 3.

If m1=m2subscriptùëö1subscriptùëö2m_{1}=m_{2} and m3=m4subscriptùëö3subscriptùëö4m_{3}=m_{4}, then the corresponding trapezoidal central configuration must be an isosceles trapezoid.

Proof.

By using the two equations (13) it follows that that the diagonals are equal, that is, r13=r24subscriptùëü13subscriptùëü24r_{13}=r_{24}. To conclude the proof it is enough to observe that a trapezoid with diagonals of equal length is an isosceles trapezoid. ‚àé

Proposition 4.

If m1=m3subscriptùëö1subscriptùëö3m_{1}=m_{3} and m2=m4subscriptùëö2subscriptùëö4m_{2}=m_{4}, then the corresponding trapezoidal central configuration must be a rhombus.

Proof.

By using the two equations (14) it follows that r14=r23subscriptùëü14subscriptùëü23r_{14}=r_{23}. It follows that the quadrilateral is either a isosceles trapezoid or a rhombus.

If it is an isosceles trapezoid the diagonals have equal length, and from equation (13) it follows that the masses are all equal. From the first of equation (21) it follows that the bases are equal, that is r12=r34subscriptùëü12subscriptùëü34r_{12}=r_{34}. Moreover, from equations (12) and (13) we have that all the exterior sides are equal. The quadrilateral is then a square. In either case the quadrilateral is a rhombus.

‚àé

Cors and Roberts [9] proved that in any co-circular configuration with a given ordering of the mutual distances the masses must be ordered in a precise fashion, that is, the set of masses {m1,m2,m3,m4}subscriptùëö1subscriptùëö2subscriptùëö3subscriptùëö4\{m_{1},m_{2},m_{3},m_{4}\} is totally ordered. We now want to obtain an similar result in the case of trapezoidal central configurations. Because of the different geometry, however, it turns out that the set of masses is not totally ordered. In fact, in this case, it is only possible to obtain the following weaker result

Theorem 1.

Any trapezoid central configuration in Œ©Œ©\Omega satisfies

m3‚â§m4‚â§m2andm3‚â§m1.formulae-sequencesubscriptùëö3subscriptùëö4subscriptùëö2andsubscriptùëö3subscriptùëö1m_{3}\leq m_{4}\leq m_{2}\quad\mbox{and}\quad m_{3}\leq m_{1}.

Before proving this we present two important inequalities needed in the proof of the theorem.

Lemma 2.

Let œï:I‚Üí‚Ñù:italic-œï‚Üíùêº‚Ñù\phi:I\to\mathbb{R} be a decreasing differentiable function on an interval I‚äÇ‚Ñùùêº‚ÑùI\subset\mathbb{R}. Suppose that x1‚â§x2‚â§x3‚â§x4subscriptùë•1subscriptùë•2subscriptùë•3subscriptùë•4x_{1}\leq x_{2}\leq x_{3}\leq x_{4}, then

œï‚Äã(x2)‚àíœï‚Äã(x3)œï‚Äã(x1)‚àíœï‚Äã(x4)‚â§1.italic-œïsubscriptùë•2italic-œïsubscriptùë•3italic-œïsubscriptùë•1italic-œïsubscriptùë•41\frac{\phi(x_{2})-\phi(x_{3})}{\phi(x_{1})-\phi(x_{4})}\leq 1.
Proof.

The proof is straightforward. Since x1‚â§x2‚â§x3‚â§x4subscriptùë•1subscriptùë•2subscriptùë•3subscriptùë•4x_{1}\leq x_{2}\leq x_{3}\leq x_{4} and œïitalic-œï\phi is decreasing, then œï‚Äã(x1)‚â•œï‚Äã(x2)‚â•œï‚Äã(x3)‚â•œï‚Äã(x4)italic-œïsubscriptùë•1italic-œïsubscriptùë•2italic-œïsubscriptùë•3italic-œïsubscriptùë•4\phi(x_{1})\geq\phi(x_{2})\geq\phi(x_{3})\geq\phi(x_{4}). It follows that œï‚Äã(x1)‚àíœï‚Äã(x4)‚â•œï‚Äã(x2)‚àíœï‚Äã(x3)italic-œïsubscriptùë•1italic-œïsubscriptùë•4italic-œïsubscriptùë•2italic-œïsubscriptùë•3\phi(x_{1})-\phi(x_{4})\geq\phi(x_{2})-\phi(x_{3}). Since both sides of the inequality are positive we obtain

œï‚Äã(x2)‚àíœï‚Äã(x3)œï‚Äã(x1)‚àíœï‚Äã(x4)‚â§1,italic-œïsubscriptùë•2italic-œïsubscriptùë•3italic-œïsubscriptùë•1italic-œïsubscriptùë•41\frac{\phi(x_{2})-\phi(x_{3})}{\phi(x_{1})-\phi(x_{4})}\leq 1,

which is our claim. ‚àé

Lemma 3.

Any trapezoidal central configuration in Œ©Œ©\Omega satisfies

r232r142‚â•r34r12,superscriptsubscriptùëü232superscriptsubscriptùëü142subscriptùëü34subscriptùëü12\frac{r_{23}^{2}}{r_{14}^{2}}\geq\frac{r_{34}}{r_{12}},

Proof.

We are now ready to prove Theorem 1.

Proof of Theorem 1.

Let œï:‚Ñù+‚Üí‚Ñù:italic-œï‚Üísuperscript‚Ñù‚Ñù\phi:\mathbb{R}^{+}\to\mathbb{R} be defined by œï‚Äã(x)=x‚àí3italic-œïùë•superscriptùë•3\phi(x)=x^{-3}, then œïitalic-œï\phi is a decreasing function. œï‚Äã(x2)‚àíœï‚Äã(x3)œï‚Äã(x1)‚àíœï‚Äã(x4)=r14‚àí3‚àír24‚àí3r23‚àí3‚àír13‚àí3‚â§1.italic-œïsubscriptùë•2italic-œïsubscriptùë•3italic-œïsubscriptùë•1italic-œïsubscriptùë•4superscriptsubscriptùëü143superscriptsubscriptùëü243superscriptsubscriptùëü233superscriptsubscriptùëü1331\frac{\phi(x_{2})-\phi(x_{3})}{\phi(x_{1})-\phi(x_{4})}=\frac{r_{14}^{-3}-r_{24}^{-3}}{r_{23}^{-3}-r_{13}^{-3}}\leq 1.

Next, we verify that m2‚â•m4subscriptùëö2subscriptùëö4m_{2}\geq m_{4}. Multiplying the second equation in (21) and the second equation in (22), we find

m2m4subscriptùëö2subscriptùëö4\displaystyle\frac{m_{2}}{m_{4}} =r122‚Äãr233r342‚Äãr143‚ãÖ(r133‚àír343)‚Äã(r143‚àír243)(r123‚àír243)‚Äã(r133‚àír233)absent‚ãÖsuperscriptsubscriptùëü122superscriptsubscriptùëü233superscriptsubscriptùëü342superscriptsubscriptùëü143superscriptsubscriptùëü133superscriptsubscriptùëü343superscriptsubscriptùëü143superscriptsubscriptùëü243superscriptsubscriptùëü123superscriptsubscriptùëü243superscriptsubscriptùëü133superscriptsubscriptùëü233\displaystyle=\frac{r_{12}^{2}r_{23}^{3}}{r_{34}^{2}r_{14}^{3}}\cdot\frac{(r_{13}^{3}-r_{34}^{3})(r_{14}^{3}-r_{24}^{3})}{(r_{12}^{3}-r_{24}^{3})(r_{13}^{3}-r_{23}^{3})}
=(r12‚Äãr232r34‚Äãr142)2‚ãÖr14r23‚ãÖ(r133‚àír343)(r133‚àír233)‚ãÖ(r243‚àír143)(r243‚àír123).absent‚ãÖsuperscriptsubscriptùëü12superscriptsubscriptùëü232subscriptùëü34superscriptsubscriptùëü1422subscriptùëü14subscriptùëü23superscriptsubscriptùëü133superscriptsubscriptùëü343superscriptsubscriptùëü133superscriptsubscriptùëü233superscriptsubscriptùëü243superscriptsubscriptùëü143superscriptsubscriptùëü243superscriptsubscriptùëü123\displaystyle=\left(\frac{r_{12}r_{23}^{2}}{r_{34}r_{14}^{2}}\right)^{2}\cdot\frac{r_{14}}{r_{23}}\cdot\frac{(r_{13}^{3}-r_{34}^{3})}{(r_{13}^{3}-r_{23}^{3})}\cdot\frac{(r_{24}^{3}-r_{14}^{3})}{(r_{24}^{3}-r_{12}^{3})}.

All the fractions in the equation above are greater than or equal to one. In fact, the first fraction is greater than or equal to one by Lemma 3, the second fraction because r14‚â•r23subscriptùëü14subscriptùëü23r_{14}\geq r_{23}, and the last two fractions because r23‚â•r34subscriptùëü23subscriptùëü34r_{23}\geq r_{34} and r12‚â•r14subscriptùëü12subscriptùëü14r_{12}\geq r_{14}, respectively. This shows that m2‚â•m4subscriptùëö2subscriptùëö4m_{2}\geq m_{4}.

Finally, using equations (20) and (16) we find that

m1m3=r143r233‚ãÖr122r342‚ãÖr233‚àír343r123‚àír143=r143r233‚ãÖr122r342‚ãÖ(r243‚àír343)(r243‚àír143)‚ãÖ(r133‚àír233)(r133‚àír123).subscriptùëö1subscriptùëö3‚ãÖsuperscriptsubscriptùëü143superscriptsubscriptùëü233superscriptsubscriptùëü122superscriptsubscriptùëü342superscriptsubscriptùëü233superscriptsubscriptùëü343superscriptsubscriptùëü123superscriptsubscriptùëü143‚ãÖsuperscriptsubscriptùëü143superscriptsubscriptùëü233superscriptsubscriptùëü122superscriptsubscriptùëü342superscriptsubscriptùëü243superscriptsubscriptùëü343superscriptsubscriptùëü243superscriptsubscriptùëü143superscriptsubscriptùëü133superscriptsubscriptùëü233superscriptsubscriptùëü133superscriptsubscriptùëü123\frac{m_{1}}{m_{3}}=\frac{r_{14}^{3}}{r_{23}^{3}}\cdot\frac{r_{12}^{2}}{r_{34}^{2}}\cdot\frac{r_{23}^{3}-r_{34}^{3}}{r_{12}^{3}-r_{14}^{3}}=\frac{r_{14}^{3}}{r_{23}^{3}}\cdot\frac{r_{12}^{2}}{r_{34}^{2}}\cdot\frac{(r_{24}^{3}-r_{34}^{3})}{(r_{24}^{3}-r_{14}^{3})}\cdot\frac{(r_{13}^{3}-r_{23}^{3})}{(r_{13}^{3}-r_{12}^{3})}.

All the fractions in the equation above are greater than or equal to one. To me more precise, the first two fractions are greater than or equal to one because r14‚â•r23subscriptùëü14subscriptùëü23r_{14}\geq r_{23} and r12‚â•r34subscriptùëü12subscriptùëü34r_{12}\geq r_{34}, respectively. The last two fractions because r14‚â•r34subscriptùëü14subscriptùëü34r_{14}\geq r_{34} and r12‚â•r23subscriptùëü12subscriptùëü23r_{12}\geq r_{23}, respectively. Hence, m1‚â•m3subscriptùëö1subscriptùëö3m_{1}\geq m_{3}, and the proof is complete.

‚àé

Remark.

From numerical experiments it appears that m1subscriptùëö1m_{1} can be larger or smaller than either m2subscriptùëö2m_{2} and m4subscriptùëö4m_{4}. For example choosing

On the other hand if

We now show that, as a consequence of Theorem 1, if two of the masses are equal, there are strong restrictions on the shape of the allowed central configuration.

Proposition 5.

For any trapezoidal c.c. in Œ©Œ©\Omega, if either m2=m4subscriptùëö2subscriptùëö4m_{2}=m_{4} or m1=m3subscriptùëö1subscriptùëö3m_{1}=m_{3} the configuration is a rhombus and the remaining two masses are necessarily equal. If m3=m4subscriptùëö3subscriptùëö4m_{3}=m_{4}, then the configuration is an isosceles trapezoid and the other two masses are necessarily equal.

Proof.

First we consider the case m1=m3subscriptùëö1subscriptùëö3m_{1}=m_{3}. By the proof of Theorem 1 we have that m1‚â•m3subscriptùëö1subscriptùëö3m_{1}\geq m_{3} and the expression

m1m3=r143r233‚ãÖr122r342‚ãÖ(r243‚àír343)(r243‚àír143)‚ãÖ(r133‚àír233)(r133‚àír123)subscriptùëö1subscriptùëö3‚ãÖsuperscriptsubscriptùëü143superscriptsubscriptùëü233superscriptsubscriptùëü122superscriptsubscriptùëü342superscriptsubscriptùëü243superscriptsubscriptùëü343superscriptsubscriptùëü243superscriptsubscriptùëü143superscriptsubscriptùëü133superscriptsubscriptùëü233superscriptsubscriptùëü133superscriptsubscriptùëü123\frac{m_{1}}{m_{3}}=\frac{r_{14}^{3}}{r_{23}^{3}}\cdot\frac{r_{12}^{2}}{r_{34}^{2}}\cdot\frac{(r_{24}^{3}-r_{34}^{3})}{(r_{24}^{3}-r_{14}^{3})}\cdot\frac{(r_{13}^{3}-r_{23}^{3})}{(r_{13}^{3}-r_{12}^{3})}

is the product of three numbers greater than or equal to one. If m3=m1subscriptùëö3subscriptùëö1m_{3}=m_{1}, it follows that each of the fractions in the equation above is equal to one. From the first two fractions we obtain r14=r23subscriptùëü14subscriptùëü23r_{14}=r_{23} and r12=r34subscriptùëü12subscriptùëü34r_{12}=r_{34}, respectively. From the last two fractions we obtain r14=r34subscriptùëü14subscriptùëü34r_{14}=r_{34} and r12=r23subscriptùëü12subscriptùëü23r_{12}=r_{23}, respectively. This yields a rhombus. Moreover, comparing the two equation (14) we find that m2=m4subscriptùëö2subscriptùëö4m_{2}=m_{4}.

Second we consider m2=m4subscriptùëö2subscriptùëö4m_{2}=m_{4}. From the proof of Theorem 1, we have that m2‚â•m4subscriptùëö2subscriptùëö4m_{2}\geq m_{4} and

m2m4=(r12‚Äãr232r34‚Äãr142)2‚ãÖr14r23‚ãÖ(r133‚àír343)(r133‚àír233)‚ãÖ(r243‚àír143)(r243‚àír123).subscriptùëö2subscriptùëö4‚ãÖsuperscriptsubscriptùëü12superscriptsubscriptùëü232subscriptùëü34superscriptsubscriptùëü1422subscriptùëü14subscriptùëü23superscriptsubscriptùëü133superscriptsubscriptùëü343superscriptsubscriptùëü133superscriptsubscriptùëü233superscriptsubscriptùëü243superscriptsubscriptùëü143superscriptsubscriptùëü243superscriptsubscriptùëü123\displaystyle\frac{m_{2}}{m_{4}}=\left(\frac{r_{12}r_{23}^{2}}{r_{34}r_{14}^{2}}\right)^{2}\cdot\frac{r_{14}}{r_{23}}\cdot\frac{(r_{13}^{3}-r_{34}^{3})}{(r_{13}^{3}-r_{23}^{3})}\cdot\frac{(r_{24}^{3}-r_{14}^{3})}{(r_{24}^{3}-r_{12}^{3})}.

This expression is the product of four numbers greater than or equal to one. If we require m2=m4subscriptùëö2subscriptùëö4m_{2}=m_{4}, then from the second fraction we obtain r14=r23subscriptùëü14subscriptùëü23r_{14}=r_{23}. Moreover, the first fraction now reduces to (r12/r34)2superscriptsubscriptùëü12subscriptùëü342(r_{12}/r_{34})^{2}, and thus we must have r12=r34subscriptùëü12subscriptùëü34r_{12}=r_{34}. The last two fractions give r23=r34subscriptùëü23subscriptùëü34r_{23}=r_{34} and r14=r12subscriptùëü14subscriptùëü12r_{14}=r_{12}, yielding again a rhombus.

Third, suppose m3=m4subscriptùëö3subscriptùëö4m_{3}=m_{4}. From equation (22), we have that

m3m4=r24‚àí3‚àír14‚àí3r13‚àí3‚àír23‚àí3subscriptùëö3subscriptùëö4superscriptsubscriptùëü243superscriptsubscriptùëü143superscriptsubscriptùëü133superscriptsubscriptùëü233\frac{m_{3}}{m_{4}}=\frac{r_{24}^{-3}-r_{14}^{-3}}{r_{13}^{-3}-r_{23}^{-3}}

If m3=m4subscriptùëö3subscriptùëö4m_{3}=m_{4} this implies that r24‚àí3‚àír14‚àí3=r13‚àí3‚àír23‚àí3superscriptsubscriptùëü243superscriptsubscriptùëü143superscriptsubscriptùëü133superscriptsubscriptùëü233r_{24}^{-3}-r_{14}^{-3}=r_{13}^{-3}-r_{23}^{-3}. Consequently,

r24‚àí3‚àír13‚àí3=r14‚àí3‚àír23‚àí3.superscriptsubscriptùëü243superscriptsubscriptùëü133superscriptsubscriptùëü143superscriptsubscriptùëü233r_{24}^{-3}-r_{13}^{-3}=r_{14}^{-3}-r_{23}^{-3}.

If r23<r14subscriptùëü23subscriptùëü14r_{23}<r_{14}, then r23‚àí3>r14‚àí3superscriptsubscriptùëü233superscriptsubscriptùëü143r_{23}^{-3}>r_{14}^{-3} and the right-hand side of equation above is negative, contradicting the fact that r13‚â•r24subscriptùëü13subscriptùëü24r_{13}\geq r_{24}. Hence, r23=r14subscriptùëü23subscriptùëü14r_{23}=r_{14} and r13=r24subscriptùëü13subscriptùëü24r_{13}=r_{24}. Since a trapezoid with equal diagonals is an isosceles trapezoid, the configuration is an isosceles trapezoid. The equality of the masses m1=m2subscriptùëö1subscriptùëö2m_{1}=m_{2} then follows from the first of equations (20). This completes the proof.

Remark.

Note that m1=m2subscriptùëö1subscriptùëö2m_{1}=m_{2} does not imply that the configuration is an isosceles trapezoid. For instance, a non-symmetric central configuration with m1=m2subscriptùëö1subscriptùëö2m_{1}=m_{2} can be found numerically to be

see Figure (3).
